race.name: Vapor Trail 125
race.tagline: 125-mile high-altitude Colorado mountain gravel in Leadville.

climate.description: High-altitude mountain conditions with extreme altitude challenges.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through high-altitude Colorado mountains. 125-mile distance with significant elevation and extreme altitude.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional CO event. High-altitude 125-mile challenge is significant but moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Vapor Trail 125 is a 125-mile high-altitude gravel race in Leadville, Colorado‚Äîmountain terrain with extreme altitude (10,000ft+). The combination of 125 miles and extreme altitude is a serious challenge, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it in Tier 3. Leadville provides moderate access. Summer mountain weather at altitude adds complexity.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A serious high-altitude 125-mile mountain gravel challenge. Worth it for the altitude and distance test. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers seeking organization or field depth.

final_verdict.one_liner: 125-mile high-altitude Colorado mountain gravel in Leadville.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you want a high-altitude endurance test‚Äîyes, it's a serious challenge. If you want organization or pro field depth‚Äîlook elsewhere.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better high-altitude events: Leadville 100, Crusher in the Tushar. For similar regional events: other CO mountain gravel races.

logistics.airport: Denver (DEN) 2 hours or Colorado Springs (COS) 2 hours
logistics.lodging_strategy: Leadville has limited lodging. Book early or stay in nearby towns.
logistics.food: Leadville has limited dining. Stock nutrition for 125 miles.

suffering_zones.label: First Third
suffering_zones.desc: 40 miles in, altitude begins to bite.

suffering_zones.label: Halfway
suffering_zones.desc: Halfway point, 60+ miles to go at altitude.

suffering_zones.label: The Grind
suffering_zones.desc: 90 miles in at altitude, mental game begins.

course_description.signature_challenge: 125-mile distance at extreme altitude (10,000ft+) with mountain climbing.

non_negotiables.why: 125 miles at 10,000ft+ requires extensive endurance and altitude preparation.
10,000ft+ base elevation requires serious altitude acclimation.
125 miles at altitude requires extreme pacing discipline.

logistics.explanation: 10 PM start under F Street bridge creates parking chaos in downtown Salida, though neutral rollout with group pee break shows some organization. Eric Henderson noted pre-race "moody skies with distant lightning," but logistics feel amateur‚Äîno packet pickup details listed and volunteers doing chain maintenance suggests friendly chaos over professional systems.

length.explanation: 125 miles of mostly singletrack delivers punishing endurance challenge. Anonymous elite racer reached first aid at 2am after 10pm start: "It had taken me 4 hours to go 26 miles! I was not used to this!" Race director's advice is "Start slow, and then go even slower"‚Äîfinishing times of 12-21+ hours prove every mile has consequence. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: Mostly singletrack with mandatory hike-a-bike sections and exposed terrain. Anonymous elite racer hit "steep, loose switchbacks that just may have been the gnarliest that I have ever seen" before Aid 1. Continental Divide Trail addition features "off-camber trails" with water crossings and switchbacks, plus technical night riding for 8+ hours. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: First 14 miles gain nearly 3,000 feet according to Eric Henderson's post-race analysis. Chalk Creek to Hancock delivers 18 miles with 3,969 feet of climbing, followed by Canyon Creek's "strenuous 45 minute hike" to 12,600 feet. Old Monarch Pass adds another 9 miles gaining 2,500 feet‚Äîrelentless vertical punishment throughout. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: Temperatures swing from 32¬∞F at alpine sections to 80¬∞F afternoon highs, creating serious clothing strategy. Anonymous racer reported stopping to add winter gloves and wind jacket during night hours. Katie stayed "warm in puffy jacket" on Canyon Creek descent, while 2024 race had "just below freezing" alpine temperatures before sunrise. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Course averages over 10,000 feet with peaks near 13,000 feet. Kathy Duryea waited for sunrise at 12,600 feet on Granite Mountain, calling it "a sight to behold." Eric Henderson noted only "mild shortness of breath" after pre-race acclimatization rides at 11,000+ feet, but most riders face immediate altitude shock from mile one. Among the highest-altitude events in gravel, on par with Badlands.

adventure.explanation: Canyon Creek features mandatory dismount "where the trail was actually falling off the mountain with a 120' drop to the left." Kait Boyle described riding under "full moon over the mountain landscape" as "unreal." Night riding technical singletrack at 12,000+ feet while crossing Continental Divide five times delivers backcountry adventure most never see.

prestige.explanation: Elite riders like Cory Wallace and Alex Howes compete, with Wallace setting 2025 course record of 12:00:00. However, 150-rider field cap means minimal media coverage. Jeff Kerkove's 10-year veteran status and women's course record holder Kait Boyle provide some credibility, but this remains mountain biking's cult classic, not mainstream prestige.

race_quality.explanation: Three aid stations for 125 miles of technical terrain stretches support thin, though volunteers provide exceptional service including chain cleaning by race director Mike Franco. Anonymous elite racer praised volunteers as "so energized" with filled bottles and breakfast burritos, but basic infrastructure suggests grassroots operation over professional production.

experience.explanation: Jeff Kerkove captured it perfectly: "It felt like I paid to be smashed with a hammer while breathing through a straw for 14 hours. When can I sign up again!" Kait Boyle called it "the most fun I've had racing my bike in...maybe ever." The 30.5% finishing rate in 2025 proves it delivers transformative Type 2 fun.

community.explanation: Small 150-rider field creates tight bonds among survivors, and proceeds support local trail groups. But the mountain bike purist attitude comes with gatekeeping vibes. You'll find your people if you're into technical suffering, otherwise you're just tourist. As Becky Gardner's Town Connection puts it: "The first time I heard of the Vapor Trail 125 was about ten years ago when I first moved to Salida, CO..."

field_depth.explanation: 150 riders total with no notable pro names means you're racing weekend warriors with expensive lights. The 65% finishing rate suggests most of the field is undertrained weekend heroes. Depth comes from suffering tolerance, not racing pedigree. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: At $175-200, riders access curated Colorado singletrack crossing private land normally off-limits. Monarch Crest Trail and Rainbow Trail singletrack would take weeks to piece together independently. Anthony Campono noted "50+ volunteers split between 5 aid stations" providing exceptional service, though thin aid station coverage for technical terrain.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $100-150. Salida isn't Aspen but lodging during mountain biking season won't be cheap. You'll need serious night lighting for 8-9 hours and gear for 30¬∞F to 80¬∞F swings. No packet pickup details suggests you're figuring out logistics yourself. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Pirelli Cinturato Gravel M
primary.why: Mixed-terrain specialist. Balanced grip and speed for variable conditions.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: Are these idiots for real?
videos.description:
When you've watched this, Watch this - https://youtu.be/euBN2ODkFYw 
Then see if your comments are still valid!

While these signs strongly advise pedestrians to stay off cycling trails for safety, the legal situation is more complex.

The Countryside and Rights of Way Act 2000 (CROW Act) gave the public a new legal right of access to "open access land" in England and Wales. This land primarily includes mountain, moor, heath, and downland, and much of the land managed by Forestry England falls under this category. This means that, by law, the public has a right to walk on this land.

Therefore, while a sign with a crossed-out person is a critical safety warning and should be respected, it does not always represent a legal prohibition. It's a way for Forestry England to manage risk and guide people towards safer, more suitable walking routes.

This reality highlights a significant challenge for forest management: balancing public access rights with the need for user safety. 

I have my opinions on this and clearly not everyone agrees, which is absolutely fine as is your right to agree or disagree. I'm not changing my opinion on the response I got but clearly the signage is not as clear cut as it first appeared.

Let me know your thoughts in the comments below....


Follow me on Socials

videos.title: Insane Motorcycle Crashes & Moments | CrashBanditoNL
videos.description:
Video is Solely for educational Purposes Only! 

Get ready to be amazed, entertained, and educated! CrashBanditoNL brings you an action-packed motorcycle compilation showcasing the best (and sometimes worst) of two-wheeled thrills. From pro riders to everyday enthusiasts, there‚Äôs something for everyone. Don‚Äôt forget to like, comment, and subscribe for more awesome motorcycle content!

crashbanditos7@gmail.com

videos.transcript:
[music]
In Blood Mountain, Georgia, a biker was
riding with his friends and carving
through every corner. But in one turn,
he made a few crucial mistakes.
The rider made several mistakes. He
leaned too far. His riding line was off.
And most importantly, he was going too
fast because he entered the corner at
that speed. His line fell apart, and he
tried to lean even lower to make it
through. But at that point, it just
wasn't possible.
No, for sure not.
>> Luckily, the rider was okay and
continued his ride afterward.
>> Yeah, the cop gave me two tickets.
>> A group of dirt bikers went out for a
ride. Some dirt bikes don't have turn
signals, and this clip shows the
dangerous consequences of that.
In situations like this, always keep
extra distance when riding behind a
group ride. Since some dirt bikes don't
have turn signals, you have to read
their body position, slow down early,
and stay prepared for sudden turns.
Fortunately, the rider was fine and he
decided to take a slower, more careful
approach in the future.
In Dallas, Texas, a writer shows why
using a night visor actually matters
when you're riding at night.
WOOHOO!
We found the keys right here. Slid all
that way, guys. 100 m.
>> The answer is 328 places.
In Sydney's Motorsport Park, a rider,
Jay Jenkowski, [music]
was head towards his track day where he
planned a beautiful ride. At the track,
he was carving through the beautiful
corners of the circuit. But one turn
ended his fun for the day.
The rider hangs off too far without
bringing his upper body with him, so he
ends up putting pressure on the bars. At
a little throttle that lightens the
front wheel, it hits a bump, the bars
twitch, and the front finally tucks. A
classic front end wash out.
>> Such a bummer. Like I'm completely fine.
It happens.
>> Luckily, the biker is perfectly fine. To
avoid this yourself, hang off just
enough. Keep your chest low and use your
legs, not your arms to hold you up. Stay
light on the bars and roll on the
throttle smoothly so the front keeps its
grip. By the way, Jay has a really solid
channel for anyone interested in Moto Vo
setups. He shares great tips and tricks
on how to mount your cameras, capture
clean footage, and get those perfect
riding shots. So, make sure to check him
out. On the streets of Turkey, a rider
was going way too fast. And when a small
truck moved into his path, he crashed.
>> This is why you need to slow down,
especially when you're lane splitting or
filtering.
Sometimes just a small distraction is
enough to make you crash.
The rider said he got target fixated,
but you're probably wondering on what.
There was a horse to his right. Target
fixation can happen to anyone. Your eyes
lock onto something and your bike
follows. Always keep your focus on where
you want to go, not on the distraction.
Yeah.
>> In the beautiful city of Tlisi, Georgia,
two bikers were riding through their
green light when suddenly a family
risked their lives by walking straight
through a red light.
The other rider wasn't able to stop in
time, but luckily no one was injured,
though this could have ended much worse.
In the US, an estimated 260,000 crashes
every year involve people running red
lights. Even with a green light, always
scan both sides. People running red
lights can appear out of nowhere, and a
quick check can prevent a serious crash.
A rider from Riverhead, New York, was
standing still when an illegal group
ride passed by. Moments later, a cop
pulled up, mistaking him for one of
them, leaving the rider totally shocked.
>> I'm not doing anything, man. I'm not
doing it. I'm street legal, man.
>> I'm not doing anything. I'm street
legal.
>> What everybody doing?
>> I ride the trail, man. I am.
>> I'm recording this, TOO.
>> I'M NOT DOING I'm street legal. I got I
got one stop.
Everything's up to date. I'm not on
that, man.
>> What is all this?
Pull it over right now. PULL IT OVER.
>> I'M NOT TRAIL. I don't ride with you,
man.
>> You got a plane?
>> Yeah, I'm 100%.
>> Yeah, man. I don't do all that.
>> Doesn't matter. You see everybody riding
all over the place? What's the name of
this group?
>> I don't know, man. I don't I'm not on
that dirt bag [ __ ] man.
>> Are you the fall guy that just stops so
that we talk to you?
>> I don't do that [ __ ] man. I'm telling
you. You want my information? Every
>> Everything's up to date.
>> I'm not on that bull. Huh? And surely
>> just go home. Don't be a part of this.
>> No, man.
>> Just go home.
>> All right.
>> Be smart.
>> I don't I don't associate with these
kids.
>> I ride trails.
>> The writer was at the wrong place at the
wrong time. The police thought he was
complicit in the group ride and treated
him like a fall guy, but he genuinely
wasn't part of it. What would you have
done in this situation? Let me know in
the comments below.
In the mountains of Georgia, a rider was
cruising along, but there was a lot of
gravel on the road. And with gravel
comes a higher risk. Hard breaking can
make you crash much faster than on clean
pavement.
The writer went into the corner too
fast, and when he saw the fence, he
panicked. With all that loose gravel on
the ground, he slid out immediately. On
gravel, panic braking is a recipe for a
crash. Always slow down before the
corner and use smooth inputs to stay in
control.
When you go through a corner, even if
it's not very sharp, you still need to
lean with it. If you don't, you're going
to miss the turn. And that's exactly
what happened to this rider.
It looks like the rider made two
mistakes. First, he didn't lean into the
corner and went in too straight. And
second, he glanced to his left for a
split second, losing focus and drifting
straight instead of following the turn.
The writer said he was completely fine
thanks to his protective gear. So always
wear your gear.
In Istanbul, Turkey, a biker was lane
splitting. And sure, lane splitting
comes with its risks. But what happened
here was absolutely not the rider's
fault.
I mean, who expects someone to just open
their door on the highway? Even in
traffic, nobody does that. Luckily, the
rider was fine. A car door opening on
the highway is completely unexpected and
extremely dangerous. This is why drivers
should always check their mirrors before
opening a door, no matter the situation.
A rider from Asen in the Netherlands was
out cruising when he realized he was
going way too fast for an upcoming
corner. So he bailed to the grass path
on the side, but at the end of that path
was a massive pothole he didn't see
coming.
Luckily, he was wearing proper
motorcycle boots, so nothing happened
besides a close call. But this isn't the
only incident in the Netherlands where a
rider decides to cut through the grass
next to the main road.
>> Oh god.
>> Shortcuts like this look safe, but
they're full of hidden dangers,
potholes, uneven ground, mud, or debris.
Leaving the asphalt should always be a
last resort, not a plan.
Riding in Deals Gab, North Carolina can
be incredibly satisfying, but if someone
slides out, that satisfaction usually
disappears unless the slide happens to
be a beautiful one. And in this case, it
was a nice one.
Oh,
good slide though.
>> The rider went too low in the corner and
scraped the ground which caused him to
lowside the bike. When you lean too far
without the right speed, traction or
body position, the tires can lose grip
and the bike will lowside. Always find
your limits gradually. Keep your body
stable and avoid pushing beyond what the
corner allows.
>> That was nice as hell how you slid that
though. That was bad as hell, Tom.
[laughter]
He was like sl [screaming]
like he was coming into a performance.
>> Zoo, he was running.
This writer from Turkey is the perfect
example of what I want Crash Bandito
fans to be. Someone who sees danger
before it even happens. Pay attention to
this bus.
The biker moved to the side of the
intersection because he saw in his
mirrors that the bus driver wasn't going
to stop. The clip went viral this week
in the country and even the tour
operator responded to the incident.
There is an English saying by Jeep by
twice.
The writer bought a cheap knockoff of a
quad lock. Now he doesn't just need a
new mount for his moped. He needs a new
phone, too. Always invest in quality
gear. You really do get what you pay
for.
A writer from Japan showed another
classic example of why you shouldn't
give too much throttle in a turn. And he
found out the hard way.
Luckily, the rider was completely fine,
but his bike took a long time to get
pulled out of that ditch.
A rider from Bavaria was messing around
on his moped, but zigzagging on any
two-wheeler is never a good idea.
A rider from Massachusetts had a really
close call with a car that didn't see
her.
And this is exactly why you need to slow
down and always assume other drivers
don't see you. Give yourself enough time
and space to react because sometimes
your awareness is the only thing that
keeps you safe. A group of riders in
India were already unstable from heavy
braking but then something else happened
that really finished the situation off.
The rider had nothing serious, but he
definitely needed a moment to chill. And
of course, he was worried about his
bike. What happened here is simple. He
braked hard, then hit a bump while the
suspension was already compressed. When
that happens, your tires can momentarily
lose contact with the road. And with no
grip, the bike became uncontrollable.
That's why you should always try to
break before the bumps, not on them, and
ease off a little if the road surface is
rough.
>> In the West Midlands, UK, Moad was
riding down towards the Ring Road in
Wolverampton when this happened.
>> Hi there, guys. Welcome back to Moto
Dad. How we all doing today? Are we
good?
Flipping pret.
Wally idiot.
Absolute prat.
Use your freaking eyes, you
idiot. Sorry guys, I never swear. I do
apologize. It's your blood boiling.
>> We've got clip from his mid turkey where
this rider shows exactly why you
shouldn't ride on the shoulder.
Luckily, the biker was fine and got
right back up. But remember, a lot of
people suddenly use the shoulder legally
or illegally, and they're not expecting
a rider to be there. That's what makes
it so dangerous. Before we get into some
good vibes from New York, here's an
interaction from the Bronx between a
moped rider and a car driver.
>> Are youing idiot?
>> Are you stupid?
>> You you local
Huh? I was going to you.
I love you.
Come here. I love you.
I love you. [laughter]
>> [laughter]
>> Yo, I catch that lacking. I catch that
lacking. Wait here. I catch him lacking.
I catch him lacking.
>> Can my Spanish- speakaking viewers let
me know in the comments what they were
saying? And if it's something bad, just
give me a quick summary. A rider from
New York was filling up his gas when
someone in need approached him, asking
for something that might seem simple to
most of us, but not for everyone.
>> I got you.
>> Give me one second.
You know how low you are?
Yeah, a little bit. This is how you read
an oil dipstick. You'll see two holes or
lines, one marking the minimum oil level
and the other marking the maximum. If
the oil is below that minimum mark, it's
time to refill.
I got you. Thank you. No problem. In the

Every car is different, but for many
modern vehicles, one of the most common
oils is 5W30.
That should do it.
>> And buy you a drink or something.
>> No, it's okay. I don't want your money.
>> No, it's okay. I'm just here to help
out, you know. Thank you so much.
>> No problem. I hope I can help out a
little bit. You know,
>> you really did. Thank you.
>> Enjoy the rest of your day.
>> 2 minutes of kindness cost you nothing,
but it can mean the world to an elderly
person. Thank you for watching. Please
consider to like and subscribe if you
enjoyed the video.

videos.title: 5000 Meters of Climbing in 125km - 2025 XC Marathon World Championships
videos.description:
Pinkbike's World Cup Videographer, Charlie Coquillard, received a VERY last minute offer to cover the epic XC Marathon World Championships in the Valais region of Switzerland. He had to say yes as the method of following the race was flying point to point in a helicopter to try and keep up with the fastest athletes in the world. The grueling 125km course across some of the most scenic peaks in the region would test the riders to their maximum. This is the race through Charlie's eyes.

Like Pinkbike? Try Trailforks, the best mountain bike trail mapping app.
https://applink.trailforks.com/4EpG/fvn5pxf9

Subscribe for more content from the pulse of mountain biking.

Champery World Champs 2025 Videos:
‚Ä¢ DH Bike Tech: https://youtu.be/p0JYzN1jMBo
‚Ä¢ Course Preview: https://youtu.be/272XMu_8RdU
‚Ä¢ Inside The Tape: https://youtu.be/tIHH6xeDC4k
‚Ä¢ XC Marathon Helicopter Coverage: https://youtu.be/MQ6bzIGnHg8
‚Ä¢ Junior Story Of The Race: https://youtu.be/KwYLzO0tz5Y
‚Ä¢ Elite Story Of The Race: https://youtu.be/aDT5baaW0q4
‚Ä¢ Average Biker Rides World Cup Track: https://youtu.be/Lbo1c_i_uFM

Website - https://pinkbike.com
Podcast - https://pinkbike.link/pbpodcast
Instagram - https://instagram.com/pinkbike
Facebook - https://facebook.com/pinkbikecom
videos.transcript:
[Music]
Mountain bike fans, welcome to the 2025
Marathon XC World Championship. Yes, I
am a Daniel reporter. However, we got a
call last minute last night informing us
that there was a spot left on the
chopper that was going to go and cover
the XC marathon race today. Obviously, I
am no discipline expert. However, I am
going to try to show you how insane this
discipline is, how beautiful the places
they're going is, and hopefully it will
make you want to watch a little bit more
of XC Marathon in the future. So, jump
with me in the chopper and discover this
125k course through the Swiss Alps.
Unlike Daniel Racers, And athletes like
to start early when it's still cold, so
they set off at 6:00 a.m. to brave the
brisk morning of Verbier.
A little early for my taste. However,
other disciplines rarely get full
chloric life band on course. So, there's
that.
The women were starting 5 minutes after
the men. But by the 15k mark, the top 10
group had already caught up with the
back of the male pack. But wait, what
exactly is XC marathon? And how is this
Verdia course so different from a
traditional track?
>> Marathon is meaning it's just long
distance. So it's not just 42 something
kilometers. Uh it's just really long. Uh
here it's 125ks and 5,000 m of climbing.
What's special here? It's a A2B race. Uh
normally the marathon would do a big
loop and and here it's crossing many
valleys uh from Via to Breeze.
After almost crash landing because the
sun was facing the wrong direction,
blinding out our pilot, we got to
witness some rather interesting piloting
strategies such as the OPPO balance
cornering technique, the sit on the
saddle downhill strategy, or some great
classic like the god, I'm not making
this one, or the timeless block pass
well known from motocross afficionados.
Interestingly, the course also included
a set of slippery metal stairs, which I
thought was a bold choice considering
the cost of Afghan Switzerland for a
foreigner, but some interesting shapes
were thrown on that bit of ashalt.
So, we have arrived at the third spot
after a short hilly ride, and it's a bit
weird, but there is like an immature
race going on. So, it's like a bunch of
middle-aged men just kind of like
pushing their bike through the rocks.
Um, I'm not really sure when the pros
are supposed to storm through, but that
seems like it might be a bit of an
issue. The pros eventually did storm
through, and it was indeed a little bit
of an issue with a lot of shouting and
scrambling onto rocks. But to the random
punters defense, the elites did also
struggle in those tight and technical
rock sections with a fair amount of them
deciding to dismount and run instead.
Heat. Heat.
Then it was time for the lead woman to
storm through. And what a show. A pure
display of power and skills with Kate
Courtney clearing a rock garden 98% of
the field. Men and women wouldn't ride
through without putting a foot down.
Anna Winebeer wasn't so lucky and ended
up making a small mistake which would
see her put the knee to the ground. At
this stage, she looked pretty beat up
and I didn't know if she was going to
hold on to Kate till the end.
So, we're at kilometer 80 and they're
going right there.
See that? They're going here.
That is very unintent.
So, I'm on the third and last pick. And
I think the course creator may be a
little sadistic because that pinch
climb, I mean, I don't even know if you
can call it a pinch climb. That climb is
vertical. Like, you wouldn't catch me
dead on an ebike trying to go up that.
So, as you can see, this is the end. But
wait,
they're coming all the way from there.
Like, I can't even see the bottom. It
really doesn't do it justice, but it is
vertical. I'm going to try to go and
measure how steep it actually is.
>> 24¬∞. That's insane.
>> See this sign? It means why are you
doing this in French? And I have the
same question.
>> This is definitely an incredibly tough
course. I don't think the marathon
worlds have had just quite such a tough
course. Um, it is very special. The
course record was just below 6 hours.
Most marathon world championship have
been around 5 hours for the main maximum
plus the altitude. We're here at 2,800
m. So that makes it really tough.
[Applause]
Unfortunately, because the finish was
only 15k away and the average pace for
the top guys was 20.7k an hour, we had
to rush out As soon as the top five went
by, Keegan Swenson would cross the line
after red lining for 6 hours, 1 minute,
and 44 seconds. He didn't end up beating
the course record because of the tough
wet conditions in some sections, but
battled through the whole race to take
the lead between kilome 80 and 100.
Obby, thanks for the support. You know,
I know uh a lot of friends and family
are watching back home and uh know
everyone else. So, uh, yeah, really
excited.
>> So, it does seem like hard tails are
back in a big way. Crazy to see that
after all this technological
advancement, you can still win an XC
World Championship on one of those.
Gate Courtney would cross the line about
an hour and 10 minutes behind, and she
surely was the most excited athlete on
the planet that day.
This course is crazy. Um, I I'm honestly
can't put it into words yet, but really
really proud of this one and just really
grateful that I was able to get it over
the line on a clean ride today. It's a
super hard course. Uh, yeah, 125k, 5,000
m of climbing is insane. Um, I thought
Lebl was hard and this like took the
ante up a notch. But it's challenges
like these that I think like push us to
the edge and provide a menu to like get
the best out of yourself. And I'm really
proud I was able to do that today. To be
at the end of a 4,000 ft climb, hiking,
carrying the bike is is just such mental
torture. Honestly, I was calling it the
portage of positivity. My mental coach
and I worked on the hiking section a
little bit. Um, and it was even harder
than I imagined it would be. Yeah. I I
feel like that's where I really just had
to like get gritty and make it up that
the like scariest or hardest part of the
course was that last descent. I had like
a tiny sidewall cut just probably bad
luck hit a rock somewhere. Um and I rode
a flat tire basically from the top of
that to the to the finish line which is
the most technical descent of the
course. So it really reminded me that
like you know things are earned but
they're also given and I'm grateful that
uh it worked out in the end.

videos.title: How Does it Feel to Drive a Sprint Car?
videos.description: What does it feel like to drive a sprint car? We asked several of the World of Outlaws NOS Energy Drink Sprint Car Series drivers for their best explanation.
videos.transcript:
yeah I remember the very first time I
got in it and hit the gas it was just
incredibly surprising how reactive it
was
it's like strapping uh it's like
strapping yourself to a rocket
it's like a roller coaster old calacity
wooden roller coaster with no no tracks
but going you know 100 100 mile an hour
so there's a lot of stuff going on a lot
of intensity
you know you got the steering wheel
trying to rip out of your hands your
feet getting tired from pushing the
brake as hard as you can brake pedal as
hard as you can and you know and on top
of that you're going over 100 miles an
hour
never been on a boat either way those
guys are getting thrown around up and
down
um you know hanging on for an Eight
Second Ride you can compare it to maybe
bull riding or something like that it's
running from the cops it's uh you know
scoring your game-winning run in a high
school baseball games
it's just that kind of feeling lap after
lab
I think that's why all
of you know we race 80 90 100 times a
year because because we're in love with
it and we're addicted to it
foreign
[Music]
[Applause]

videos.title: Jay P's Tour Divide bike: Rodeo Labs Flannimal deep dive.
videos.description:
Let's dig in to Jay Petervary's WINNING bike setup for the 2021 Tour Divide B2B / Great Divide Classic bikepacking race.  Check out all the ins and outs of his steel Rodeo Labs Flaanimal 5.0 including all his personal touches.

Check out the video of JayP' unpacking his Clothing + Kit here: https://youtu.be/j-RQ28SZyec

GIVE BACK and PAY IT FORWARD! Join our #trailmagic family on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/dirtyteethmtb  

Dirty Teeth merchandise: https://dirtyteethmtb.bigcartel.com
¬†
All my gear recommendations: https://www.amazon.com/shop/dirtyteethmtb

rider_intel.search_text: The provided video transcripts do not contain any content related to the Vapor Trail 125 gravel race in Leadville, Colorado. The transcripts cover unrelated cycling content including mountain bike crashes, XC marathon racing in Switzerland, and general cycling incidents. No actionable intelligence about the Vapor Trail 125 race course, terrain, conditions, gear recommendations, or race strategies can be extracted from these materials.
